sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: What a state I am in! Before he came, nothing mattered; I felt so free. But now that he has come, goodness knows from where, my heart is filled with his dear self, and my home will be no home to me when he leaves. Doctor, do you think he—

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: If there's life in his fate, then he will live long. But what the medical scriptures say, it seems—

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Great heavens, what?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: The scriptures have it: "Bile or palsy, cold or gout spring all alike."

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Oh, get along, don't fling your scriptures at me; you only make me more anxious; tell me what I can do.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: Taking snuff The patient needs the most scrupulous care.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: That's true; but tell me how.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: I have already mentioned, on no account must he be let out of doors.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Poor child, it is very hard to keep him indoors all day long.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: What else can you do? The autumn sun and the damp are both very bad for the little fellow—for the scriptures have it:
"In wheezing, swoon or in nervous fret,
In jaundice or leaden eyes—"

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Never mind the scriptures, please. Eh, then we must shut the poor thing up. Is there no other method?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: None at all: for, "In the wind and in the sun—"

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: What will your "in this and in that" do for me now? Why don't you let them alone and come straight to the point? What's to be done then? Your system is very, very hard for the poor boy; and he is so quiet too with all his pain and sickness. It tears my heart to see him wince, as he takes your medicine.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: The more he winces, the surer is the effect. That's why the sage Chyabana observes: "In medicine as in good advices, the least palatable ones are the truest." Ah, well! I must be trotting now. Exit

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Well, I'm jiggered, there's Gaffer now.

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: Why, why, I won't bite you.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: No, but you are a devil to send children off their heads.

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: But you aren't a child, and you've no child in the house; why worry then?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Oh, but I have brought a child into the house.

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: Indeed, how so?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: You remember how my wife was dying to adopt a child?

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: Yes, but that's an old story; you didn't like the idea.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: You know, brother, how hard all this getting money in has been. That somebody else's child would sail in and waste all this money earned with so much trouble—Oh, I hated the idea. But this boy clings to my heart in such a queer sort of way—

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: So that's the trouble! and your money goes all for him and feels jolly lucky it does go at all.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Formerly, earning was a sort of passion with me; I simply couldn't help working for money. Now, I make money and as I know it is all for this dear boy, earning becomes a joy to me.

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: Ah, well, and where did you pick him up?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: He is the son of a man who was a brother to my wife by village ties. He has had no mother since infancy; and now the other day he lost his father as well.

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: Poor thing: and so he needs me all the more.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: The doctor says all the organs of his little body are at loggerheads with each other, and there isn't much hope for his life. There is only one way to save him and that is to keep him out of this autumn wind and sun. But you are such a terror! What with this game of yours at your age, too, to get children out of doors!

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: God bless my soul! So I'm already as bad as autumn wind and sun, eh! But, friend, I know something, too, of the game of keeping them indoors. When my day's work is over I am coming in to make friends with this child of yours. Exit

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Uncle, I say, Uncle!

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Hullo! Is that you, Amal?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Mayn't I be out of the courtyard at all?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: No, my dear, no.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: See, there where Auntie grinds lentils in the quern, the squirrel is sitting with his tail up and with his wee hands he's picking up the broken grains of lentils and crunching them. Can't I run up there?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: No, my darling, no.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Wish I were a squirrel!—it would be lovely. Uncle, why won't you let me go about?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Doctor says it's bad for you to be out.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: How can the doctor know?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: What a thing to say! The doctor can't know and he reads such huge books!

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Does his book-learning tell him everything?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Of course, don't you know!

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: With a sigh Ah, I am so stupid! I don't read books.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Now, think of it; very, very learned people are all like you; they are never out of doors.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Aren't they really?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: No, how can they? Early and late they toil and moil at their books, and they've eyes for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: No, no, Uncle; I beg of you by your dear feet—I don't want to be learned, I won't.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Dear, dear; it would have been my saving if I could have been learned.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: No, I would rather go about and see everything that there is.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Listen to that! See! What will you see, what is there so much to see?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: See that far-away hill from our window—I often long to go beyond those hills and right away.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Oh, you silly! As if there's nothing more to be done but just get up to the top of that hill and away!

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Uncle, do you think it is meant to prevent your crossing over? It seems to me because the earth can't speak it raises its hands into the sky and beckons.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: No, they don't have time for that sort of nonsense. They are not crazy like you.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Do you know, yesterday I met someone quite as crazy as I am.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Gracious me, really, how so?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: He had a bamboo staff on his shoulder with a small bundle at the top, and a brass pot in his left hand, and an old pair of shoes on; he was making for those hills straight across that meadow there. I called out to him and asked, "Where are you going?" He answered, "I don't know, anywhere!" I asked again, "Why are you going?" He said, "I'm going out to seek work." Say, Uncle, have you to seek work?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: He had a bamboo staff on his shoulder with a small bundle at the top, and a brass pot in his left hand, and an old pair of shoes on; he was making for those hills straight across that meadow there. I called out to him and asked, “Where are you going?” He answered, “I don't know, anywhere!” I asked again, “Why are you going?” He said, “I'm going out to seek work.” Say, Uncle, have you to seek work?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Of course I have to. There's many about looking for jobs.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: How lovely! I'll go about, like them too, finding things to do.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Suppose you seek and don't find. Then—

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Wouldn't that be jolly? Then I should go farther!

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: I see! I think you had better be getting well first; then—

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: But then you won't want me to be learned, will you, Uncle?

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: What would you rather be then?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I can't think of anything just now; but I'll tell you later on.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Very well. But mind you, you aren't to call out and talk to strangers again.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: But I love to talk to strangers!

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Suppose they had kidnapped you?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: That would have been splendid! But no one ever takes me away. They all want me to stay in here.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: I am off to my work—but, darling, you won't go out, will you?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: No, I won't. But, Uncle, you'll let me be in this room by the roadside.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: Curds, curds, good nice curds.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Curdseller, I say, Curdseller.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: Why do you call me? Will you buy some curds?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: How can I buy? I have no money.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: What a boy! Why call out then? Ugh! What a waste of time.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I would go with you if I could.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Yes, I seem to feel homesick when I hear you call from far down the road.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: Lowering his yoke-pole Whatever are you doing here, my child?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: The doctor says I'm not to be out, so I sit here all day long.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: My poor child, whatever has happened to you?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I can't tell. You see I am not learned, so I don't know what's the matter with me. Say, Dairyman, where do you come from?

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: From our village.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Your village? Is it very far?

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: Our village lies on the river Shamli at the foot of the Panch-mura hills.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Panch-mura hills! Shamli river! I wonder. I may have seen your village. I can't think when though!

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: Have you seen it? Been to the foot of those hills?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Never. But I seem to remember having seen it.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: How wonderful!

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: And your women with red sarees fill their pitchers from the river and carry them on their heads.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: That's right, child.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: And the first day doctor lets me go out, you are going to take me to your village.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: I will, my child, with pleasure.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: And you'll teach me to cry curds and shoulder the yoke like you?

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: Dear, dear! Why should you sell curds? No, you will read big books and be learned.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: No, I never want to be learned.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: Will you have some curds?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: But I have no money.

sp.speaker: Dairyman
sp.p: No, no! You'll make me happy if you take some. Exit

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Curds, curds, good nice curds—from the dairy village—

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: What's all this row?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Won't you sound the gong, Watchman?

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: Time has not yet come.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Some say time has not yet come, and some say time has gone by!

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: One day the doctor himself may take you there by the hand.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: When will this great doctor come for me?

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: One greater than he comes and lets us free.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Say, what's going on there in that big house?

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: That's our new Post Office.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Whose?

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: The King's.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Will he write to me?

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: One fine day there may be a letter for you.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: A letter for me?

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: The King sends tiny notes to little boys.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Oh, how lovely!

sp.speaker: Headman
sp.p: Who is yelling after me?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Will you tell the postman it's Amal who sits by the window?

sp.speaker: Headman
sp.p: The King indeed! Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Please don't mock me.

sp.speaker: Headman
sp.p: I'll tell the King about you. Exit

sp.speaker: Sudha
sp.p: I am Sudha.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: What do you do?

sp.speaker: Sudha
sp.p: I gather flowers.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I wish I could pick flowers for you.

sp.speaker: Sudha
sp.p: Be good and sit still. I'll come back.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: You won't forget me?

sp.speaker: Sudha
sp.p: I won't forget you. Exit

sp.speaker: Boys
sp.p: We're off to play.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Don't go. Play here.

sp.speaker: Boys
sp.p: How jolly!

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Take my toys.

sp.speaker: Boys
sp.p: You won't want them back?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Boys
sp.p: We'll come again. Exit

sp.p: No, darling.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I fear my fakir'll pass.

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: I am the fakir.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Where have you been?

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: To the Isle of Parrots.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Has the King sent me a letter?

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: It is on the way.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I can see the postman coming.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: How do you feel to-day?

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I feel awfully well.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Bad sign.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Oh God!

sp.speaker: Headman
sp.p: Here's your letter from the King! Shows blank paper

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: Please don't mock me.

sp.speaker: Gaffer
sp.p: It is his letter.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I cannot see it.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Our Sovereign King comes to-night!

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: On the second watch?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: RoyalPhysician
sp.p: Open all doors and windows!

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I feel very well.

sp.speaker: Madhav
sp.p: Ask a gift from the King.

sp.speaker: Amal
sp.p: I shall ask him to make me his postman.

sp.speaker: Sudha
sp.p: Amal!

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: He's asleep.

sp.speaker: Sudha
sp.p: Tell him Sudha has not forgotten him.
